Crime Noire
While it might be easy to criticize Blues and Bullets (a suitably noirish" title in its own right) for trying too hard when it comes to getting its Noire stamp of approval there is no denying that what A Crowd of Monsters have lovingly crafted with their first episode of a five episode season - a format that has become increasingly popular for the adventure game genre - is a suitably stylish and visually splendid recreation of the crime genre.  Featuring a real life tough-as-nails protagonist who was literally cut from the cloth of the Noire genre
recommended:
the man responsible for bringing down the notorious mob boss Al Capone with his group of untouchables.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=487116956
The Noire genre is often characterized by wise-cracking cynical tough guys who often find themselves embroiled in incredibly bleak situations and Blues and Bullets hits the ground running right from its opening moments which feature missing children locked up in what looks like someones underground dungeon. With one of the children managing to escape from their holding cell the gamer is then given the opportunity of trying to save one of the other children or make a bolt for it. Suffice to say it doesn't end particularly well and sets up a disturbing and dismally bleak opening for what is looking like 2015 slow burn for the year.

While the Noire genre is often criminally under-looked when it comes to gaming what does exist in this cannon is all of top notch quality. Some of the best games ever released come from this genre - Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Father
hoursPlayed:
Grim Fandago and L.A. Noire immediately spring to mind - so it would appear A Crowd of Monsters have their work cut out for them if they wish to join this esteemed club but based on the first episode of Blues and Bullets I have no doubt whatsoever that they won't achieve the same kind of critical plaudits the above mentioned games all received if they can keep this kind of momentum going in future episodes.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=486923915
Taking on the role of retired cop Elliot Ness the player is pulled into a world of kidnapping and sacrificial murder when he accepts the job from his former nemesis Al Capone
voteText:
whose granddaughter has been one of the children kidnapped. While the first episode starts out slowly things soon pick up when you come across the first murder victim whose life has been brutally snuffed out and it is left up to you to scour the site for clues that tell you exactly what happened and hopefully lead you further down the rabbit hole. The investigation portions of the game play out very much like MURDER: SOUL SUSPECT where you search for clues and then arrange them into a sequence that makes sense. It's a simple process of investigation but effective. The game also does spice things up every now and then by plunging our former hero into gun-battle situations but thankfully these are not overused since this is the kind of game where the narrative needs to remain within focus and not get bogged down by its own game mechanics.

Blues and Bullets is also one of the most visually arresting games to come along in a long while. Captured entirely in black and white with splashes of red that literally cause many of the scenes to pop immediately reminded me of Sin City. I absolutely adored the art style and as Elliot Ness moves from one location to the next there are enough "WOW" moments to keep the player pushing on for more. I particularly loved the gun battle where Ness's thoughts where visualized as words dropping from the sky in which he could take cover from behind while shooting a host of baddies. This was without a doubt one of the absolute highlights of the first episode and something that almost left me speechless in the way it was delivered. Blues and Bullets also comes with a stirring bluesy soundtrack that is worth picking up alone. Having the voice actor who reprised Geralt of Rivia in all The Witcher games taking on the role of Elliot Ness was also a stroke of genius because his voice seems tailor made to fit that of the legendary law man.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=487108002
Not everything is perfect though. Elliot Ness's pacing seems a little off and it takes some getting used to his walking speed which feels like you are controlling the worlds oldest turtle. Animations can also come off as incredibly stiff and the lipsync feels like it needs a bit more work but honestly these are just nitpicks because Blues and Bullets is shaping up finely to be one of this years greatest adventures. Who knows - maybe one day when the whole season has run its course it can sit proudly with the likes of Gabriel Knight and Grim Fandango. Here is holding thumbs it does. Fans of episodic adventure games rejoice because there is a new possible classic on the horizon!

reviewText:
Blues and Bullets is an episodic alternative history noir game developed by A Crowd of Monsters. The first episode was released in July 2015 with the second due to be released in March of 2016.

I will keep this review updated with each chapter I complete.

Gameplay takes place in third person as you control Eliot Ness, the police officer who caught and locked up the great, Al Capone. Eliot has now retired from being a cop and runs his own diner, called Blues and Bullets.  This game reminded me quite a bit of L.A Noire as you search for clues for a crime. There is only one crime scene to investigate in this episode but it is a gruesome one at that. There is a small element of gun play, which is very basic at best; it is done via an “on rails” mechanic similar to that of Time Crisis or Blue Estate. The gun play so far has a very small part to play in the game overall.

Graphically, the game is represented in a black and white noir style visual. This art style just looks awesome, whilst the graphics themselves aren’t stunningly good, the black and white tricks your eyes into thinking it is better looking than it actually it. The animation is slightly on the poor side, but nothing that can’t be ignored.  Eliot is voiced by none other than Doug Cockle (the voice of Geralt from the Witcher franchise), and the rest of the voice acting is all done to a very high quality.

I was completely hooked onto the story right from the start of the game, there isn’t a slow ramp in excitement like most adventure games like this, and you get right into the nitty-gritty from the get-go. The ending of episode 1 leaves you wanting more as the plot takes a huge turn of events. There are plans for there to be another 4 episodes released, I am hoping they speed up the development cycle of them, as I think 9 months between episodes is a bit too much in my opinion.

There isn’t any aspect of difficulty in episode 1, the only real puzzle can be completed with just a matter of trial and error and the gun play scenes have checkpoints at every corner so even if you do die, you don’t have to replay a whole lot of content. I am looking forward to see how they make the gameplay elements of this game have more of a challenge in future episodes.

Episode 1 took me just about two hours to complete; this was with finding all interactable objects throughout the scenes to get an achievement. I found out at the end of the chapter, that finding all of these objects unlocks a “Bobble head” mode, which is always a classic cheat mode that used to be included in game. It will be interesting to see whether you can activate this mode in future episodes or whether it is only to be used in episodes you have already completed!

Sadly I did have a couple of technical problems with Blues and Bullets. I suffered two random crashes of the game that took me straight back to desktop, with no error message or warnings. There were no signs that the game was suffering performance issues, it did only happen when completing a scene, never mid gameplay. Thankfully the game saves at the end of each scene you complete, but this does leave room for game save file corruption.  The game can be played with keyboard and mouse; normally for third person view games I opt for a keyboard and mouse controls, especially ones with any form of gunplay, sadly I could not do it with Blues and Bullets. Firstly the onscreen controls do not show any keyboard controls; only Xbox controls. Secondly, the cursor in game has a fairly big glitch where it just shows as a blank white square. You have to move your cursor to the bottom right hand corner of the screen for it not to be visible even when using a controller.

To sum up, Blues and Bullets is so far a very interesting adventure game that has a lot of potential. Hopefully the technical problems are cleaned up before the next release of the series comes out. If you are a fan of the Noire themed films and games, this game is definitely going to be for you. It’s a fairly quick paced game which is something that a lot of adventure games can’t boast about so even the casual players amongst you will definitely get some enjoyment here.

If you are on the fence about the game still, you can purchase just episode 1 for £3,99 which should give you a good amount of content to see whether you will enjoy the rest of the series, provided the developers don’t change it drastically or you can purchase the complete season for £14,99. Right now I would be completely happy paying £14,99 for this season, it does a lot of things right and the only negative points are technical problems which will hopefully be patched in the future.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

reviewText:
Former retired detective Eliot Ness is called back to duty when children start going missing and police refuse to follow leads. Getting approached by a strange yet familiar character while on shift at the local diner brings an opening to get back into the game and bring some justice to his small piece of the world.

Opening episode was like a good book, hard to put down page turner that ended with a bang leaving you wanting more. Similar to the telltale series a playthrough will take around 2hrs. While movie-like by nature, you do receive tasks to arrange a puzzle-board containing collected photographic evidence along with including some interesting albeit easy gunplay segments. Would like to see more options with dialog choice in future eps and perhaps open areas up for further exploration. Given some of the detail a lot of it felt glossed over and short lived.

Performance issues seems to have been fixed as of last patch, check the forums to be sure. Gamepad would be suggested but keyboard/mouse is managable, No controls needed to be mapped so the option was not available. Resolutions scaled upto 4k+ and the game provided several presets for shadows and otherwise, should run on a range of systems.

With aesthetics that seem inspired by Sin City/Max Payne, wonderful soundtrack and great voice work from memorable characters including Capone himself. Blues in Bullets is a series worth recommending taking a look at, just don't expect much of a challenge. Cheers folks.

8.5/10


genre: adventure game in 3rd person

You play as Eliot Ness , former cop , who is made to abandon his now peaceful life working in his diner, in order to investigate the disappearance of a child in the corrupted city of Santa Esperanza.

+ Presentation is generally nice, although inconsistent, character models are well designed, great atmosphere, although a bit morbid at times, red is the outstanding colour.
+ Fantastic soundtrack, great voice acting and memorable characters.
+ First episode was a bit slow at start, like reading a book , an interesting one though that is hard to put down, but near the end the game really shines both in gameplay and story.
+ Gameplay wise it's a traditional adventure game in 3rd person , where you examine things to find clues , speak with people choosing the appropriate questions and answers. Some choices you make might matter in next episodes, so think wisely. No puzzles, other than a murder scene where you have to complete the puzzle of the murder. A shooting action scene, that is pleasant enough and a few QTEs that are easy enough and just add to the tension of the moment.
+ Good duration for an episode, seemed longer than a telltale one, especially if you take your time and examine everything it's around 3 hours.

- Very slow pace at the beginning, even for an adventure game.
- Hope next episodes will add more to the gameplay variety, especially puzzles (that will be relevant to the story though).

Blues and bullets seemed like another story driven adventure game that lacked something vital gameplay wise, like most adventure games that come out these days. But after the first half or so, the game started to shine, especially the murder scene was incredible, although a bit brutal and morbid, so children beware. Dark game in all aspects, in the same level of quality as telltale games or the recent life is strange. More advertisement advised to the developers, since the game can truly become one of the best story driven adventure games of the year. Highly recommended !!!!

This review concerns Episode 1. For Episode 2 review, see here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/vicrabb/recommended/384380/

In a world where you can find hotels in the sky and mob bosses in submarines..., well, eeer, let me rephrase that. In a world where Eliott Ness stepped down as a cop and opened a diner, he's contacted by an old friend to help him to find a member of his family. But it seems that the clues are pointing you towards something more darker than it seems...

The game is an episodic one, so only the first is released now and setting the story. The opening is showing children captive of a strange sect/cult/maniac. You're taking the control of a little girl first before switching to Ness. Even if for now, the plot needs more explanation (because it's the first episode), you're directly thrown into that dark world and waiting for more after that cliffhanger.

And the gameplay is similar to Telltale: you choose your answer, you make decisions that will influence the story (though I'm waiting for the rest of the episodes, because I've chosen to be the gentle and helping player and not the bitter or bad one). You have also some Quicktime Events, though they're not the core of the gameplay.

But contrary to any Walking Dead or The Wolf is Among Us - I don't know for the other series -, you're also having some shooting sequences (you cover, you aim, you place your crosshair on the bad guy and you shoot) in a pure rail shooter ambiance. You have also the Clue Mode and the Investigation Board when you need to find what happened earlier: you look at the clues, you find the number required in order to be thorough and you're putting the right clue in the right place on your Investigation Board (though I don't know the English name as my interface was in French).

The real strong point is probably the graphics: everything is in black and white, apart for every item that may be in red (blood, carpets, lipstick, clothes, etc etc..). Even at one moment, you get a rail shooter sequence between words that appear! Everything is made to put you into a dark ambiance. The soundtrack is also very good, very '40 - '50.

And I'm very impatient to discover the second episode. That game has a huge potential. It's really enjoyable, even if you're not in an open world. But you get hooked by everything.

Definitively a must-have!

This review will be for Chapter 1.

Graphics-wise, the game looks like LA Confidential, but feels darker. The textures are detailed enough, but the animation can get a bit unrealistic at times.  For the best graphics experience, go to Options and make sure the graphics settings are set to your native resolution. When I started the game it chose a lower resolution for me and I didn't realize it until I had finished the game!

The game plays like a TellTale adventure game (e.g. Walking Dead). You partake in dialog choices and there are a few real time action events where it's basically a Simon Says reflex test to press the correct keys within a certain time. There's also a shooting mode where you get to aim and shoot at certain targets.

An  interesting feature this game has is a clue-deduction system. There is one murder scene where you collect clues and finally link them all up in a kind of mental branching whiteboard. It's quite easy really, once you have all the clues. Much simpler than in the Sherlock Holmes Crimes and Punishment version where the wrong clues can lead you to the wrong conclusion. The game will block you from using the wrong clue.

Story-wise, it's pretty good for a crime mystery but I feel Chapter 1 is too short. However it's got me interested enough that when Episode 2 comes out I'll definitely play it.

Conclusion: Decent game, unique look, but I think it's still not as good as The Wolf Among Us's Chapter 1. Although I enjoyed it, I'd advise buying only Chapter 1 first to see if it's to your taste.

This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) back with a review for another indie title. This time we're going way back to the prohibition days, in an alternative-history story! Blues & Bullets is an Episodic Adventure a-la TellTale games. Blues and Bullets certainly brings it's own style to the emerging genre though, and seems to be building up into a pretty good game.

Video Review (Where I butcher the name?!?!):
https://youtu.be/-lASZ4i0XQ8

(Press Copy/Serial Key provided via Dev/Publisher of Title)

My takeaways are as follows:

Positives-

+ Good immersion and set/background visuals
+ Fitting Soundtrack, also helps capture the era
+ Very engaging story
+ Plays out like a very good movie/show
+ A pretty fun Shoot-Out sequence!

Negatives-

- Character graphics are sub-par and frankly, a bit rough
- Camera is stiff in locations to essentially hide the ugly/non-existent parts of levels
- Lost my progress after upgrading from Episode 1 to Full Season (cry)

The camera thing bugs me, but only so very little and in certain scenes. Even that is a nit-pick. The character graphics could be better, that is not so much a nitpick. This, to me, is the only flaw to the game so far. That, and the fact that I have to start over because my save was erased after upgrading from just Episode 1 to the Entire Season. All in all, Blues and Bullets is a great story and will pull you in. Well worth the money.

Verdict:
9/10

Happy Gaming!

reviewText:
I'm pleased to report - well worth the money.

A short, linear adventure, B&B scratched my itch for story-driven goodness this summer. The staples of the genre are here: broken people, dry wit, dizzying camera angles, visual metaphors and grisly murders, all painted in black and white and red. A close point of comparison theme-wise for me are Heavy Rain and LA Noire, while True Detective seems to also be an inspiration for some quirkier ideas.

There's no open world or minigames here - we get the good old Telltale formula and its main strengths are characters, noir-dialogue gems and moody atmosphere. This first episode is short, but packs in quite a lot of content and twists to satisfy.The lead actor is the same as Geralt of Rivia. Try it, you'll like it!

reviewText: Provisional thumbs up. I'm running a GTX 970, which can run most games with no problem, but the scene in the murder house turns into a slideshow, and there are no graphics settings available to turn down.  The sunlight rays coming through the windows cripple performance in that part.  The fixed camera angle and not being able to use the mouse to look at what you want to look at is pretty annoying.  That said, this game looks great, the start ot the story is intriguing, the voice acting is quite good (Geralt of Rivia as Elliot Ness!), so I'll wishlist the rest of the episodes and wait to see if they deliver.

This game is definitely worth playing. Easily made it into my favorites list and I'm excited to see what new adventures the future episodes hold.

The story itself is easy to follow and understand. You get to experience step-by-step detective work while investigating scenes and put all the pieces together like a puzzle. What a wonderful 2 hours.
It starts out strong, then it slows down for about 10-15 minutes.  Get passed those opening sequences and the game grabs hold of you and doesn't let you go until the end of the credits accompanied by an emotional blues melody.  The game is an episodic noir tale with Bioshock Infinite “Burial at Sea” dlc elements combined with the sort of moody tone of the first season of True Detective,.  On top of that you play as Geralt of Rivia without the Witcher senses.  The art direction is wonderful too!  Right when I thought I had seen all that the episode had to offer, it surprised me with some great aesthetic decisions that made me giddy.

Some cons.  At first the dialogue is rather stilted.  Don’t get me wrong: the voice acting is wonderful.  It’s the pacing of the dialogue that is stilted, and the animations are rough.  But this is common in video games given the way sound bytes are edited.  Can’t be too picky.  You get used to it very quickly though.  Other than that….the experience is great!  It’s like sipping wine….or having a glass of whiskey/Juice!  I highly recommend playing it.  Only $5.

reviewText:
Blues and Bullets is an alt-history game taking place in the fictional city of Santa Esperanza (Dunno why the devs didn't just make it take place in Chicago, there are really not many games set here, aside from Watch Dogs but that did such a ♥♥♥♥ job capturing the city it shouldn't count. The devs are Spanish so maybe they did it because they didn't feel comfortable enough to do Chicago, regardless its fine) where in Al Capone survived his time in jail and enlisted his old nemesis retired G-Man turned diner owner Elliot Ness to find his kidnapped granddaughter.

The game has a really nice atmosphere, they do a good job with the black and white aesthetic. It's also  been creative with the few twists on history it’s done so far, such as the Hindenburg disaster never occurring and the zeppelin getting bought by an eccentric millionaire to turn into a luxury hotel. The writing is good so far, Ness is likable and it’s overall interesting enough. The game is clearly going to be a mix of classic film noir with the first season of True Detective. The voice acting is solid as well, Doug Cockle, Geralt’s VA, isn’t far from home playing Ness.

Gameplay-wise it’s a little bit too railroaded for my liking to truly laud it, but so far the investigation segment was good enough to not feel braindead easy, but it still pales in comparison to Sherlock Holmes: Crime and Punishments. There are also shooting segments but these are solid enough to shake things up without ruining the pacing of the game. Adding to the railroaded feeling is that you can't really explore certain areas, you have to follow a preset path and you run into a lot of invisible walls if you don't, but on the flip side the devs take advantage of this to make some nice fixed camera angles, it lessens the game a bit but its not a deal-breaker. As far as choices go the game really hasn’t gotten into the nitty-gritty yet but you can at least roleplay Ness, whether this really affects character relationships is yet to be seen. There really isn’t any really complex dialogue segments yet either.

Overall it has better gameplay than Telltale’s recent fare, but I feel it needs more to really stand shoulder to shoulder with the current new adventure game greats. While it hasn’t instantly impressed me like Kentucky Route Zero and Life is Strange, it still got me to buy the whole season because if at the very least if it keeps up the quality of the first episode it will be a solid adventure game worth playing.

reviewText:
Blues and Bullets already screams crime noir from the title alone, but does it really have the guts to delve into its inspired roots or is the title simply misleading? Rest assured that this episodic adventure game from a Spanish team really picks up and shows promise in a genre long forgotten by gamers. Right off the bat in the first scene alone, the game has this stark contrast between black and white with touches of red dotting in once in a while. It's poignant and nostalgic and serves the setting well but mostly it's to mask the really crude texture work hidden in the darkness and the poor shadow work, though this isn't made with a big budget, so it's understandable. What the game gets right in the first few minutes it's the score. It's noir soul basically but the tracks in this game are very powerful and more fitting with the dark undertones of the game. The protagonist, Elliot Ness (who seemingly sounds too much like Geralt of Rivia) is your typical down on his luck detective with a love for violence and whiskey. It's typical in films and tv but seeing this sort of character in gaming with as plenty of backstory is rare and it's breath of fresh air to walk in his shoes. The writing also follows up on the positive side with it being relative to the genre once more. Sardonic quips and comebacks mixed with self hatred and dark comic saturate this game, and it works fantastic. Each character has their own identity though they have yet to be fully fleshed out since this is the first episode. The dark nature of crime noir gets a notch up in this game with one particular sequence being bathed in blood and gore so caution for those weak in the heart, this is not a game for fun.

The mechanics in contrast to this game however reveal the weakest aspect of the game. I understand that there are limitations given the small company, but even moving the character felt sluggish, shooting (while not an important aspect) was incredibly stilted and uneventful, and the animations range from passable to awkwardly stilted. The choices made in this game have yet to bear fruit, but I doubt I will be making a second run till the next episode fans out since you pretty much play the same scenes through and through. The games I can compare this most to are Life is Strange and The Walking Dead since they too were episodic and focused on your choices. Blues and Bullets is instantly captivating and compelling from the start and rears you into an adult tale of missing children and violence that has me excited for the next episode.

+ Dark, superb writing, brings out the distinct characters
+ Powerful soundtrack that evokes the noir feel
+ Atmosphere and visual design is top notch
+ Pacing is excellent, has me pumped for the next episode
+ One of the better usage of the Unity Engine, considering its saturation of the market
- Sluggish movement, animations, and shooting mechanics
- Game performance is subpar, my decent machine failed to keep a consistent 60fps

FINAL THOUGHTS: This game really surprised me. I didn't expect to enjoy as much as I did, which considering I really ignored the adventure genre. But the non-technical aspects of this game, are on par with the likes of Life is Strange (my current GOTY), though I have to say the writing for B&B is better.

reviewText:
Blues and Bullets is an adventure game that reminds me a lot of LA Noire and Telltale's The Walking Dead.

The game sees famed detective Elliot Ness, now retired from the police force and running a diner, pulled back in to solve a case of missing children, one missing child in particular.

It has quite a heavy focus on narrative, often times when in control of Ness you are limited to very small areas and can only walk around looking at a few items of interest before continuing with the story.
Conversation trees and dialogue choices are the main part of the gameplay, some choices more important than others but in a similar way to The Walking Dead you're often forced to make quick decisions and even when time wasn't a factor and I didn't feel the decision I made would really effect the story one way or the other I still found myself pausing to think, which to me is always a good sign.

Aside from that there are a couple of brief QTE sections and you'll get into a couple of shootouts, which are sort of on rail sections that I feel work quite well. Ness will move forward once you've killed the current enemies before stopping at the next piece of cover for you to repeat the process.
Combat involves aiming, popping out of cover and shooting. You can occasionally move from one piece of cover to another (there is no direct control though, you simply hit a button and Ness moves) but other than for a bit of variety there doesn't seem to be any point to this.

There are also crime scenes (or rather a crime scene in this first episode) for you to explore.
I hope that in future episodes more areas can be like this one was, a lot more open with a lot more to inspect and uncover.
You walk around looking at areas, occasionally zooming in to a specific location, like an overturned table, to look for more clues. These are all placed on a board and you need to match the right clues to the right heading.
For example, which clues tell you how the assault happened, which clues prove there was a witness, that kind of thing.
Nothing overly challenging and there's no penalty for choosing the wrong clue but exploring the environment and gradually piecing together what had happened kept me interested.

I really like the game's look, black and white with small dashes of colour here and there. It's very striking and fits the mood and theme very well. Performance was a little sluggish on the highest settings with a Radeon HD7800 series but absolutely fine on medium and the game still looked great, for the most part.

There are a few rough edges, animations are a little iffy in places, there's the odd graphical glitch and some people might find the pace a little slow but the story and the characters are pretty strong.
Voice acting on the main cast is very good and although this first episode is just kind of setting up the characters and the plot it's definitely got me intrigued.

If you can overlook the slow pace and some slightly rough edges I'd say it's well worth checking out.
If length is a factor I should note Episode 1 took me just under 3 hours.

An episodic adventure game set in an alternate version of the 50's that will appeal to Telltale games fans. You play as Elliot Ness, former leader of the famous Untouchables and search for... Al Capone's grand daughter, who has been kidnapped. Game plays almost exactly like The Walking Dead or Game of Thrones - you interact with objects, make a lot of difficult choices and take part in some quick time events (and even shootouts). You may feel the low budget from time to time, but apart from that, the game is top notch.

First of all it has a fantastic atmosphere - you are not sure if everything is happening for real, or if it is some kind of delirious dream. In this alternate reality, the famous Hindenburg zeppelin has been turned into a hotel floating above the city of Santa Esperanza (by a guy named... A. Ryan; Bioshock, anyone?), hight tech submarines are stationed in the docks and gruesome murders are being commited by a cultist of an extraordinary strength, who is able to torn victims arms with his bare hands. There is also a case of missing children, that have been abducted by a strange sect, whos members are wearing bird-like masks. Story looks very promising and dense.

The graphics are nice as well - developers know how to operate lightning, depth of field and colors to create something unique and intriguing. Voice overs are ok as well - the performance of two main characters is really good and pleasant to hear. Music is awesome, though it has almost nothing in common with blues.

The first episode lasts for about two hours and features several choices that will have consequences in the future. You can buy it for 5$/€ and it's totally worth it. If you like it, get the rest of the episodes without paying twice for the first one, as there is Episodes 2-5 pack available.

Great indie game with a good production value and nice attention to detail. The gameplay is pretty linear but it's very story-oriented (you make choices but they don't affect what happens that much). reviewText:
I must start with I totally dig alternate reality historical fiction. I also greatly enjoy film noir. Mix those two together with a design style that is lovingly ripped from Sin City and this purchase was a no-brainer. I've only played the beginning episode (I'm not sure the others have been released at this point), but I am hooked and ready for the rest of the story.

I will keep this brief and spoiler free.
Playing as Eliot Ness, retired from the police, you are hired by Al Capone (stay with me, this is an alternate reality, remember?) to find his kidnapped niece, Sofia. That's the basic beginning plot and that's as far as I'm going to go with the story.

The gameplay is straight adventure fair. Easy for anyone to jump in and play. You basically use one button to interact with everything. This works very well. The fighting elements of the game are very well realized. There are QTE events as well as more arcade-like gunplay sequences. For those who fear arcade-like sequences, take heart as they are not difficult, but are very well staged to make Ness feel pretty bad-@$$. Also, choices you make affect what happens later in the game. So far, the choices I have made seem to have little effect, but some of it was a very nice touch, so kudos to the writers!

Speaking of stage, this is where the game shines. The sets are stunning. The black/white/red color scheme is used to great effect. Every scene looks absolutely gorgeous and feels like a film noir. This is also partly due to the game designers choice to lock the camera. While I find this a bit annoying, I understand why they did this. They can control the camera angles so that each scene is presented at its best and they keep the noir theme running throughout. This is a narrative story, afterall.

And what about the story? So far, the writing has been excellent and the story has got me hooked. The only minor gripes are that the acting does not always live up to the writing. Al Capone is a bit ham-fisted, a bit too over the top. Some of the secondary characters feel less like professional actors and more like friends that chipped in to lend their voices to an indie project. But the actor who plays Ness truly shines. He is perfect, and that's the most important thing.

While the set graphics are absolutely out of this world, the character design and execution is a bit hit and miss. Ness, again, is beautifully realized. But some of the other characters do not quite have his definition, they feel like they were created in far less time and do not quite sit in the scenes as well as he does. All of the character animations are a bit stiff - it is clear they were all motion captured, but there's something missing to truly elevate the animation to AAA level. Lastly, the facial expressions are sorely lacking in this game. This is a game where you are talking to a number of people and their reactions and expressions can really help to engage the audience even more. Unfortunately, everyone looks like they have all been recently shot up with Botox.

Alright, but if these graphics seems so terrible, why are you giving it a thumbs up? Because the game is fantastic! My comments on the animation are minor quibbles. The animation isn't terrible, most people may not even notice. I work in 3D for a living, so these are things I notice. This game is about story and atmosphere and it does both BEAUTIFULLY!

My minor gripes with the game do little to tarnish it. Anyone who enjoys a good story and phenomenal atmosphere owe it to themselves to pick this game up.

EDIT: I almost forgot to mention one of the coolest mechanics of the game, when Ness goes into detective mode." The designers did a really nice job utilizing a simple one-button ui while still keeping it completely engaging. You encounter a grisly murder scene and are given an opportunity to deduce what happened. You search the body

I have only played the first episode but so far it's been an excellent game. Noir adventures are my jam but even if you aren't a fan of the genre I'd recommend this for the incredible graphics, music and story. The game starts off in a suspenseful situation and you're given the whole timed decision consequence scenario that is well known among Tell Tale games. Though I haven't really seen any deviation in how the story plays out through different choices. The story plays out rather quickly as you can be in a calm conversation in one episode then thrust into a fight some couple minutes later.

There's a few gun fights that play out simply in an aim and shoot, also featured are a few quick time action events. And if by chance you do happen to die the game is very forgiving and restarts right before the event. In addition there are also detective-esque moments where you will have to piece together what happened at a crime scene. There isn't any side quest deviation but you do have branching paths of Eliot Ness and another individual which slowly become connected.

Despite the monotone graphic style with sparing use of red there are incredibly detailed and vibrant environments.The episode played out in just over 2 hours and the game does leave you at a bit of a cliffhanger at the end but it gives you enough stuff packed in the episode so that it's never boring. The music and voice acting also does a great job of getting into the feel of the era. It's as polished a game as you would expect from any of the top tier developers. I did experience a little bit of lag at certain areas but nothing that hindered my playing too much. With the intriguing plot this game and stunning visuals you'll be happy about trying this one.

I recently played the first episode of this game. Throughout my gameplay the whole game felt like a movie. It was well paced, and I loved the feel of the game. It puts you in a certain mood. I recently played the first episode of this game. Throughout my gameplay the whole game felt like a movie. It was well paced, and I loved the feel of the game. It puts you in a certain mood. Bering a noir game adds to the whole feel of the game. The story is linear, as with any other storytelling type of games. What I found a bit strange was the choices you make. When you have to make a choice, you are given options relating to moods, not the actual answer that the character is going to give. So for an example the choices might be: Dismissive, Calm, Joyful. And once you select your choice, the character will give the speech/answer. This might be a bit confusing at times.

The forensic mechanic in the game is quite nice, and the crime scene board is also a concept that I haven’t seen in other games. I also love how you can recreate the scene once you have all the pieces of the puzzle. When recreating the crime scene, it felt like a TV show. It was like watching Sherlock homes recreate a crime scene, which is really cool.

Overall, I would recommend the game because of the story mainly. It is intriguing and the story seems so much bigger than what it was revealed in the first episode. Really looking forward to the next ones.

If you like mystery, detective work and good stories, you should give this game a try.

reviewText:
Overcoming a few shaky moments, the technical mishaps and the lack of polish on a few graphical elements, Blues and Bullets is a great example of taking a bizarre premise and playing it perfectly. The gameplay is nice and focused, even if the movement is a bit slow for my tastes, and the use of the Sin City-style palette works nicely for the most part, turning even the opulent Hindemburg Hotel into something deeply dark and lurid.

Combing for clues and working through dialogue is pleasantly direct, with little room for real error or combing a room for one elusive item, something a few games still fail to get right. The shooting sections, although basic, are still entertaining enough, and have the flavour of the old-school rail shooter to them which was a nice little moment of nostalgia for me at least.

Best of all, frankly, is the writing. The mystery unfolds in a few directions, rather than just pointing us in one direction explicitly, and it's refreshing to see so many genuinely competent characters - Eliot lends a steady hand and a weather eye, whereas Milton proves not to be just a comic foil, but also a very guarded and intelligent individual who always seems to be ensuring that he has the upper hand, just a little.

Is it perfect? No. The character models can look a bit dippy, and the pace and style of the game isn't going to appeal to everyone, but if you're a fan of Life Is Strange or the Telltale CYOA games, and you fancy something chock full of trenchcoats, mobsters and gothic-noir horror, this comes highly recommended. Try the first episode, see if it's for you.

Also, the reward for completing chapter 1 made me wet myself. You saucy buggers, you.

reviewText: Blues and Bullets is one of those games that, despite essentially being pieced together from other games, manages to make it work on its orn merits. At its core it plays like a modern Telltale game, mainly involving dialogue and choices, but it also takes notes from LA Noire in its aesthetics and occasional shooting, while the investigation gameplay is heavily remniscient of Sherlock Holmes: Crimes and Punishments, in which you search crime scenes for evidence and then piece them together on an evidence board yourself. The graphics sometimes have a bit of lack of polish, being an indie game, but the art style does a pretty good job of of covering the flaws, and the somewhat stilted character animations are made up for by the generally pretty good voice cast, particularly thanks to the voice of Doug Cockle (probably better known by his real name, Geralt of Rivia) as the main character.\n\nThe premise is an alternate history story about Eliot Ness, one of the real-world investigators responsible for the arrest of Al Capone. The story isn't exactly as grounded as its real-life inspiration would suggest, and certain scenes feel oddly out of place compared to the rest of the game, but for the most part it's well-told and pretty interesting so far, and left me looking forward to the next episode. The first episode spends a lot of its time setting up the story, so it feels somewhat linear, but it opens up enough later on to suggest that further episodes will do better with the pacing. Overall Blues and Bullets does a pretty good job for a first episode from a new studio, and while it is somewhat risky to buy an episodic game from a non-established developer, I thought it was worth giving it a try.

The esthetics and the main protagonist are straight up borrowed from the Sin movie, the anthagonist in the episode is borrowed from the cover of the SW:KOTOR 2 game, the constant noir whining is borrowed from Max Payne, and I have seen the thug-intellectual character somewhere before too, only I don't recall where exactly.

The strongest point of the game are probably the investigation scenes where you examine a scene and try to find clue and reconstruct what has happened. The problem is you can achieve it by mindlessly clicking on everything and then trying all the combinations. Then you have the story and the dialogues borrowed from Telltale games that try to create the illusion of important decisions. And lastly, there are very mediocre shooting gallery scenes which are just bad, and the game would be better without them.

The graphics are barely functional, and the black and white style helps to hide the fact that there are barely any textures on the objects. Despite that, the game has some glaring performance problems even on very modern hardware, which is quite unfortunate, especially since it also crashes occassionally. I never judge a game just by how it looks, but the barely adequate graphics combined with outright wooden and stiff animations sometimes really detract from the playing experience, especially during conversations (facial animations), and during the shooting sequences.

If you love noir movies and are an avid consumer of cliches, change the verdict to Yes. For me, however, the game left a foul aftertaste. It's not that it is strictly bad, but it is too mediocre to leave a lasting impression.
